item.title: [cssom-view-1, dom, pointerlock-2, pointerevents3, fullscreen, DOM-Parsing] querySelectorAll() does not state how the results are sorted
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/querySelectorAll

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

No response

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Incomplete: IMO the docs should state how are the reslts sorted.

What did you expect to see?

The Element method querySelectorAll() returns a static (not live) NodeList representing a list of elements matching the specified group of selectors which are descendants of the element on which the method was called, sorted by their appearance order inside the queried scope. (or whatever, I don't know)

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

I'm so glad MDN displaced the infamous "HTML school" or whatever it's name was, a truly SEO master job!

item.title: [html, css-images-3] Statement about applicable object-position and object-fit is wrong (?)
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/iframe

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Positioning and scaling

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

As a replaced element, the position, alignment, and scaling of the embedded document within the <iframe> element's box, can be adjusted with the object-position and object-fit properties.

I tried to apply iframe { object-fit: contain; } with several combinations of explicit width & height, overflow: hidden, even using the deprecated scrolling attribute of the <iframe>. It doesn't seem to work.

So either the rule "replaced element -> can be used with object-fit and object-position" is wrong, because it is only applicable to images and videos, or we should really provide an example.

What did you expect to see?

Either I would have expected not to see this paragraph at all, or I would have expected object-fit and object-position to work.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [html, clipboard-apis] Code snippet using the void return of canvas toBlob() function
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Clipboard/write

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Clipboard/write#write_canvas_contents_to_the_clipboard

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The code example is using canvas toBlob the wrong way (according to MDN doc) :

  • No callback is provided to the function toBlob()
  • It's using the void return of function toBlob() instead of using the callback

What did you expect to see?

Something using toDataUrl() like in this doc https://web.dev/patterns/clipboard/copy-images :

// Get canvas can add an event handler for the click event.
const canvas = document.getElementById("canvas");
canvas.addEventListener("click", copyCanvasContentsToClipboard());

async function copyCanvasContentsToClipboard() {
  // Copy canvas to blob
  const url = canvas.toDataURL();
  const blob = await fetch(url).then(response => response.blob());
  // Create ClipboardItem with blob and it's type, and add to an array
  const data = [new ClipboardItem({ [blob.type]: blob })];
  // Write the data to the clipboard
  await navigator.clipboard.write(data);
}

It may be slower than just using toBlob(), but it's simpler. Actually it may be better to use the toBlob() just to see how we use the toBlob with simple code.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLCanvasElement/toBlob

My typescript types looks like that

    /** [MDN Reference](https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/HTMLCanvasElement/toBlob) */
    toBlob(callback: BlobCallback, type?: string, quality?: any): void;

Do you have anything more you want to share?

I only tested manually and locally the corrected snippet I provided, but I didn't even try to use the toBlob() api. Maybe there is a better way with toBlob()

item.title: [html, dom] There have been a few changes to declarative shadow DOM
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/attachShadow

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Declarative shadow DOM

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

There have been some recent spec changes to declarative shadow DOM:

  • The <template> element now has a shadowrootclonable attribute, to control the clonable attribute of the shadow root for declarative shadow DOM. That should be mentioned here https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLTemplateElement.
  • The default value for clonable is no longer true for declarative shadow roots. The default is always false. See https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/attachShadow.
  • Calling attachShadow() with an existing declarative shadow root worked previously, but will now throw an exception if the mode doesn't match the existing root's mode. I don't believe this is documented anywhere, but this page says an InvalidStateException will be thrown if there's already a shadow root, which isn't exactly true.

Thanks!

What did you expect to see?

See above.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [html, uievents] Window load example regression
item.content:encoded:
The page for https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/load_event has an example showing the order in which load and DOMContentLoaded events are fired. As recently as June 13, 2023 this example worked, but since the new live sample system launched it has stopped working.

Perhaps this is because in the new system DOMContentLoaded fires before the script runs.

item.title: [html] <dialog> return value example combines two conflicting approaches
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/dialog

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Handling the return value from the dialog

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The sample JavaScript includes

// "Favorite animal" input sets the value of the submit button
selectEl.addEventListener("change", (e) => {
  confirmBtn.value = selectEl.value;
});

but confirmBtn.value is never read because favDialog.close(selectEl.value); sets the favDialog.returnValue.

This example feels like it is trying to show two different, conflicting ways to pass the return value. Either as the argument to the .close method or as the value of the confirmBtn.

What did you expect to see?

There are two possible fixes and I'm not sure which ones is preferred. If I knew I would have opened a PR.

1. Take the line:

<button id="confirmBtn" value="default">Confirm</button>

and add the formmethod attribute:

<button id="confirmBtn" value="default" formmethod="dialog">Confirm</button>

then delete this event handler entirely

// Prevent the "confirm" button from the default behavior of submitting the form, and close the dialog with the `close()` method, which triggers the "close" event.
confirmBtn.addEventListener("click", (event) => {
  event.preventDefault(); // We don't want to submit this fake form
  favDialog.close(selectEl.value); // Have to send the select box value here.
});

now clicks on confirmBtn should use the value of the button being set in the change listener.

2. Delete the change listener entirely (these lines):

// "Favorite animal" input sets the value of the submit button
selectEl.addEventListener("change", (e) => {
  confirmBtn.value = selectEl.value;
});

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

The docs for the .close method say:

An optional string may be passed as an argument, updating the returnValue of the dialog.

Alternatively the docs for the returnValue say:

Submitting a form with a method="dialog" closes the dialog and sets the return value to the value, if any, of the button or input elements of type=submit.

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Both examples seem useful so it might help people to include both just separated so it's clear what the difference between using the .close method and the formmethod="dialog" with button values is.

item.title: [html] HTML <iframe>: allow attribute needs stand-alone topic
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/iframe#allow

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

The topic named iframes

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The iframes attribute allow is used to set a permission policy for the frame. The current documentation in https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/iframe#allow is insufficient. There is quite useful information in https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Permissions-Policy#iframes - probably too much to stick into the above document.

So the proposal is to create a stand-alone document for the allow attribute, pulling in the information from the Permissions-Policy document linked above. The Permissions-Policy document then might have a reduced set of information and a cross link.

What did you expect to see?

Much of the information in https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Permissions-Policy#iframes

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

Discussion originates in #32135 (comment)

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [html] Wrong advice
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/div

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Use of lang attribute

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

As a "pure" container, the

element does not inherently represent anything. Instead, it's used to group content so it can be easily styled using the class or id attributes, marking a section of a document as being written in a different language (using the lang attribute), and so on.

What did you expect to see?

Using a lang attribute on a div, will mean that a lot of assistive techs will ignore it, as it's not an element natively announced by AT's. Kinda like having a label, and assigning it's for attribute to the wrapping div of an input field, instead of the input field itself.

I'd say this encourages developer bad practice giving this example, and causing problems for sites accessibility where people follow this advice

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [html] cancelAnimationFrame using mismatched time values in sample
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/cancelAnimationFrame

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Examples

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

In the sample, the progress variable is calculated by subtracting Date.now() from the callback time parameter.

In testing, Date.now() is epoch time, and the parameter to requestAnimationFrame looks like milliseconds since the session start.

So progress ends up being around negative 54 years .

What did you expect to see?

Matching time basis. I believe something like this would work, but not sure what is preferred or standard (which is why I'm logging and not PR'ing a fix).

const start = document.timeline.currentTime;

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

This MDN page claims Date.now() is epoch.

This MDN page claims the requestAnimationFrame parameter is equivalent to document.timeline.currentTime.

I've also run the sample snippet in the MDN sandbox to confirm the values

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [html] Connected or not?
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebSocket/WebSocket

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Multiple pages

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

From the description here, the WebSocket constructor gives me a WebSocket instance that has started connecting to the server but may not have completed this yet. Also, the send() method should fail if the socket is still connecting. And there's the open event that tells me that the connection has been opened.

Yet, none of the examples use any of it, they just create a new instance and send right away. This makes it completely blurry, how connection failures are handled. Is there always either an open or a close event and should I wait for any of these before using the socket instance? Or will the constructor actually block until the connection is either opened or failed?

More description is needed to make clear what really happens and how this thing should be used in production code.

What did you expect to see?

See above.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [fetch] Missing Request constructor duplex option
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

Parameters

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

What did you expect to see?

A note about the parameter, and that it needs to be set to "half" when using a ReadableStream body.

It would also be nice to have a row for browser compatibility.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

Chrome docs (showing how to do half-duplex fetch): https://developer.chrome.com/docs/capabilities/web-apis/fetch-streaming-requests
Related web platform test: https://wpt.fyi/results/fetch/api/request/request-init-stream.any.html?label=master&label=experimental&aligned&q=request-init-stream

Do you have anything more you want to share?

The Request class itself also has a duplex get-only property, so main page (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Request) is affected and an instance property page is missing too

item.title: [html] Using Storage change event on same page.
item.content:encoded:

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Entire Note

Note: This won't work on the same page that is making the changes  it is really a way for other pages on the domain using the storage to sync any changes that are made. Pages on other domains can't access the same storage objects.

For instance, if I'm on /myroute1 and I go into the dev tools and manually update the value, does that mean the code for /route1 won't catch the event if I do window.addEventListener("storage", (e) => {console.log(e.newValue)}). I've tried this and it seems to work.

Clarification on what it means that it doesn't work on the same page.

item.title: [html] `hgroup` accessibility concerns might need an update
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/hgroup

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

The accessibility note below the section Try it

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

There has been a lot of work done around the <hgroup> tag that might warrant an update of the accessibility warnings on this MDN page. See below.

It says <hgroup> has been removed from the W3C HTML specification, but it seems this has been added again

Quoted from an a11yproject article:

Update August 1, 2022: Steve Faulkner proposed a way to introducehgroup again, which is promising, in:
Subheadings, subtitles, alternative titles and taglines in HTML

Until browsers add the information themselves do:

Add role="group" and aria-roledescription="Heading group" as attributes to the hgroup element.
Add the subtitles in a paragraph (not a heading)

.
Then all information about the structure and connection of the headings group is given for assistive technology in the accessibility tree.

What did you expect to see?

A recommendation on how one can ensure their usage of <hroup> is accessible.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

W3C PR on element mapping for <hgroup>
Related PR on W3C

Topic stumbled upon from this article

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

What did you expect to see?

The HTMLInputElement page should mention the "cancel" event, and link to its documentation.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

The "cancel" event for <input type="file"> elements was added to the HTML standard in July 2021: whatwg/html#6735

HTML spec - cancel event
HTML spec - Common input element APIs

This feature has been supported by all modern browsers since May 2023. According to CanIUse, it currently has 83.62% global browser support. Support for this feature is already included in mdn/browser-compat-data and displays on the HTMLInputElement page.

item.title: [html] Document img auto-sizes
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLImageElement/sizes

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Value

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The auto keyword is not documented.

What did you expect to see?

The auto keyword can be used for lazy-loaded images. This makes the browser use the rendered width of the image as the computed sizes value for selecting a candidate in srcset. The value must be exactly auto (case-insensitive) or start with auto, (case-insensitive). The width and height attributes should be used when using auto. The browser's default style will force size containment (so that the rendered size is not affected by loading the image) and contain-intrinsic-size will be 300px 150px (this can be overridden by author CSS or the width/height attributes).

When using auto-sizes with picture, the auto keyword is required on the img element. The sizes attribute can be omitted on source elements.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

whatwg/html#9493

item.title: [html] Document false negatives for navigator.onLine property
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Navigator/onLine

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Top level description

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The description claims that there can be false positives, but not false negatives. However, browser not only check for LAN connectivity on Windows. Windows has two connectivity levels, internet and LAN connectivity for each network interface. If the a connection claims there is no internet connectivity, navigator.onLine returns false. Whether there's an internet connection or not, depends on a Microsoft service, that typically breaks down when using VPN. There are workarounds by editing the Windows registry to disable the check, or use a different address for the connectivity status check.

What did you expect to see?

A mention of possible false negatives, at least on Windows. Several PWA services break down when they use navigator.onLine.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/forum/all/windows-10-says-im-offline/24a9922f-e740-4b0a-94af-d7e37fef2fd3
https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/forum/all/icon-showing-no-internet-yet-there-is-internet/51f4d89c-d5e8-4b51-b781-7b8286fd33e1
https://www.reddit.com/r/PrivateInternetAccess/comments/9vz0fb/why_does_windows_think_im_offline_even_though_i/

item.title: [html] DataTransfer is not only used for Drag & Drop
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/DataTransfer

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Multiple sections/articles

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Top sidebar heading of https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/DataTransfer is "HTML Drag and Drop API"; main description states "is used to hold the data that is being dragged during a drag and drop operation"; similar wording throughout the article.

Similar wording is pervasive throughout all the pages relating to DataTransfer. For example, https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/DataTransfer/setData and https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/DataTransfer/getData refer to the data that's set/retrieved as "drag data".

What did you expect to see?

Removal of wording that implies DataTransfer is exclusively used for drag-and-drop, and add mention of other use cases where relevant.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

  • https://w3c.github.io/clipboard-apis/#clipboardevent-clipboarddata
  • https://stackoverflow.com/questions/47172409/how-to-set-file-objects-and-length-property-at-filelist-object-where-the-files-a

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Examples of non-drag-and-drop use cases:

  • ClipboardEvent#clipboardData is a DataTransfer object (used in clipboard events like copy): 
    document.addEventListener('copy', (e) => {
    assert(e.clipboardData instanceof DataTransfer)
    e.clipboardData.setData('text/html', '<h1>hello world</h1>')
})
  • Manually creating a DataTransfer object to programmatically generate a FileList to add files to an <input type="file">: 
    const dt = new DataTransfer()
dt.items.add(new File(['hello world'], 'hello.txt'))

assert(dt.files instanceof FileList)
document.querySelector('input[type=file]').files = dt.files

Possibly other use cases I'm not aware of.

item.title: [dom] Chrome has XMLNS as default namespace
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Node/isDefaultNamespace

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Example

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The first js comment is correct for the current version of Firefox, but incorrect for Chrome Version 117.0.5938.149:

  result[0].value = aHtmlElt.isDefaultNamespace(""); // true
  result[1].value = aHtmlElt.isDefaultNamespace("http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"); // false
  result[2].value = aSvgElt.isDefaultNamespace(""); // false
  result[3].value = aSvgElt.isDefaultNamespace("http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"); // true

In current Chrome, the default namespace is the XMLNS namespace.

This might also necessitate changing the following note at the top of the page:

Note: The default namespace of an HTML element is always "". For a SVG element, it is set by the xmlns attribute.

because apparently the default namespace of an HTML element is not always "" in Chrome.

I expected to see some information on the different behaviour of Chrome and Firefox.

item.content:encoded:

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Attributes

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

See whatwg/html#5465 which is going to land soon. When it does, the shadowrootmode attribute on the <template> element will be standardized.

The MDN page here: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/template#attributes looks like this:

In Chromium-based browsers, the <template> element also supports a non-standard shadowrootmode attribute, as part of an experimental "Declarative Shadow DOM" proposal. In supporting browsers, a <template> element with the shadowrootmode attribute is detected by the HTML parser and immediately applied as the shadow root of its parent element. shadowrootmode can take a value of open or closed; these are equivalent to the open and closed values of the Element.attachShadow() mode option.

That should be updated to remove the "Chromium-based browsers" language, etc., and refer to the spec.

See above.

item.title: [html] The "Navigator: languages property" documentation is missing some browser quirks
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Navigator/languages

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

No response

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The MDN page for Navigator.languages implies that the navigator.languages property and the Accept-Language header are always the same:

The Accept-Language HTTP header in every HTTP request from the user's browser uses the same value for the navigator.languages property except for the extra qvalues (quality values) field (e.g. en-US;q=0.8).

Indeed, this is implied by the specification. However, it has never been the behaviour in WebKit, as evidenced by the thread in which the feature was first implemented:

https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=163220

Instead, navigator.languages always returns an array with a single value. The relevant change to Source/WebCore/page/NavigatorBase.cpp is still standing in WebKit's most recent release.

Chrome exhibits similar behaviour on mobile devices, although not that I have noticed on the desktop: https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1345416.

There is also a relevant experiment the Chrome developers did to reduce fingerprinting by limiting what gets included in both the Accept-Languages header and in navigator.languages: https://developer.chrome.com/blog/origin-trial-for-accept-language-reduction/. Although if they did that for real (sigh), at least the text here would be correct.

What did you expect to see?

I have to admit, I'm confused and frustrated by all of this, but I think MDN could improve here by explaining that navigator.languages probably can't be trusted to provide a list of fallback languages in at least Chrome and Safari.

My suggestion is to completely remove the paragraph I quoted, since it is not true in a majority of cases, and add more implementation notes under Chrome, Safari, and Android WebView.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [console] Clarify wording around "string representation" in console.* related functions
item.content:encoded:
old text

MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/console/assert

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

The part about passing in objects

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

What should this print?

console.assert(false, { a: 1 })

In the spec text https://console.spec.whatwg.org/#assert it would seem (from my limited understanding) that it should forward everything to Logger() and it should print Assertion failed { a: 1 } like most other console methods do. That's what Chrome and Firefox do at least.


...but then on MDN there's this text: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/console/assert


which reads (to me at least; i could be mistaken) that passing console.assert(false, {a:1},{b:2}) will do String() or similar on each of those {a:1} objects
...which would seem to indicate that Node.js has the right idea:

idk man, I'm just a bit confused which one is "right"

What did you expect to see?

Rephrase the text to be a bit more clear on whether "The string representations of each of these objects are appended together in the order listed and output." means perform string coercion or print a fancy object repr.

or idk maybe a little note or some screenshots of what happens sorta like https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/console#using_groups_in_the_console which has a very nice image

or maybe a little note about how Node.js has a slightly different way of doing it

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://console.spec.whatwg.org/#assert

nodejs/node#49680

whatwg/console#77

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

Right now in a lot of the console.* methods there's this type of language used:

This is potentially confusing. It seems to indicate that said objects will all be .toString()-ed and concatenated together, sorta like this:

// obj1  objN
// A list of JavaScript objects to output. The string representations of each
// of these objects are appended together in the order listed and output.
console.info = (...objN) => {
  underlyingPrint(objN.map(x => String(x)).join(" "))
}

but that's obviously NOT what it means to convey. Instead, it means to convey that these objects are "inspected" or "pretty printed" and then "shown" (not necessarily "printed") to the console in the specified order.

The issue at hand: Should this change?

If so, here's an idea:

before after

obj1 objN
A list of JavaScript objects to output. The string representations of each of these objects are appended together in the order listed and output.

obj1 objN
A list of non-string values to inspect in the console. The method of inspection is implementation defined. Browser consoles have interactive consoles, while text-based output may pretty-print the objects.

idk tho. something more clear like that

affected pages that i could find:

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/console/info
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/console/warn
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/console/error
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/console/debug
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/console/assert

console.trace() has a pretty decent description https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/console/trace

objects Optional
Zero or more objects to be output to console along with the trace. These are assembled and formatted the same way they would be if passed to the console.log() method.

item.title: [html, css-conditional-3, selectors-4] `read-only` pseudo class behavior ambiguities in the documentation.
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/:read-only

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

:read-only

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The first paragraph states:

The :read-only CSS pseudo-class represents an element (such as input or textarea) that is not editable by the user.

However, this is inaccurate. The read-only pseudo targets editable fields that do not accept text. This can be verified by the following code:

<input type="checkbox" />
<input type="radio" />
<input type="text" />
input {
  outline: none;
}

input:read-write {
  outline: thick double blue;
}

input:read-only {
  outline: thick double red;
}

Sample output. Note how the checkbox, despite being "editable by the user," is targeted by the read-only styles.

What did you expect to see?

I think this should be mentioned in the documentation. That read only has unexpected (at least from my perspective) behavior. This could be an ambiguity-related issue similar to what can occur with in-range or other input-type specific pseudos, but I believe the documentation could benefit from this clarity.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

Not beyond the replicable code.

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No.

item.title: [dom] `isTrusted` property in `Event` isn't indicated whether this event was generated by a user action
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/isTrusted

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

property description

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

MDN says

The isTrusted read-only property of the Event interface is a boolean value that is true when the event was generated by a user action, and false when the event was created or modified by a script or dispatched via EventTarget.dispatchEvent().

But the focus event is filed with isTrusted = true even if the focus is changed by calling focus() on a element in script without a user action, e.g. page calls focus() to focus a element right after it's loaded.

What outlined in the spec is:

isTrusted is a convenience that indicates whether an event is dispatched by the user agent (as opposed to using dispatchEvent()). The sole legacy exception is click(), which causes the user agent to dispatch an event whose isTrusted attribute is initialized to false.

What did you expect to see?

Perhaps something in line with the spec.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-event-istrusted

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

Note : If the selector selects an id and this id starts with a number (0-9), a syntax error is returned.

item.title: [html] HTMLElement.dataset: using the `in` operator is unsafe
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLElement/dataset

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Accessing Values

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The in operator is exposed to the usual risk of prototype pollution, so anything added to Object.prototype and other classes in the inheritance chain of DOMStringMap will be in the dataset but not in hasOwnProperty .

What did you expect to see?

Change in to hasOwnProperty or add a caveat.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

	Object.prototype.bad = function() { console.log("bad prop")};
	var e = document.body.querySelector("#test"); // <span id="test" data-man="1">
	console.log("man", "man" in e.dataset, "bad", "bad" in e.dataset); // man true, bad true
	console.log("man", e.dataset.hasOwnProperty("man"), 
            "bad", e.dataset.hasOwnProperty("bad"));// man true, bad false

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

main section(?)

The keydown, keyup, and keypress pages don't explicitly mention that keyboard events are also "generated"/can be installed on by window, document, <html> and <body>. The keydown page implies that is the case via the sentence
If not caught, they bubble up the DOM tree until they reach Document, but it would be better to be explicit, and the the keyup page currently lacks this sentence. item.title: [html] No page for HTMLSelectElement.value
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/select

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

No response

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

While doing the Svelte tutorial (part: Select bindings), I had difficulties to understand that the value attribute of <selected> always contains the value of the selected <option>.

In fact the MDN article about the <select> element doesn't mention value as an attribute of <select> nor does it describe the above mentioned relation between the values of <selected> & its <options>.

What did you expect to see?

I expected to see...

  1. something that doesn't only describe that the options have value attributes, but the <selected> element as well.
  2. a description of the relation between the value of <selected> & its <options>.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

What helped me to understand & try out the relation (as mentioned above) was the interactive example of w3schools Select value Property.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<body>

<form>
  Select your favorite fruit:
  <select id="mySelect">
    <option value="apple">Apple</option>
    <option value="orange">Orange</option>
    <option value="pineapple">Pineapple</option>
    <option value="banana">Banana</option>
  </select>
</form>

<p>Click the button to change the selected fruit to banana.</p>

<button type="button" onclick="myFunction()">Try it</button>

<script>
function myFunction() {
  let val = document.getElementById("mySelect").value
  alert(val)             // (*)
}
</script>

</body>
</html>

I added the (*)-line so that I could see the changing value of <selected> in action (depending on the selected option.

Do you have anything more you want to share?

I'm sure that the relation between <select> and its <options> is described somewhere (on a lower level(?)) - probably some article that describes general behavior of form elements.
But (especially for a beginner - like me) it would be super helpful to at least have a link to such an article - or better: a description right in the relation right in this article.

item.title: [html] Example given on blockquote page is incorrect according to the HTML spec
item.content:encoded:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/blockquote

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Try it

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The example given places the attribution for the quotation inside blockquote element, which incorrect according to the HTML specification.

What did you expect to see?

The example should place the quotation attribution outside the blockquote element, eg. in figcaption element:

<figure>
  <blockquote cite="https://www.huxley.net/bnw/four.html">
    <p>Words can be like X-rays, if you use them properlytheyll go through anything. You read and youre pierced.</p>
  </blockquote>
  <figcaption>Aldous Huxley, <cite>Brave New World</cite></figcaption>
</figure>

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

The HTML specification (https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/grouping-content.html#the-blockquote-element) states: Attribution for the quotation, if any, must be placed outside the blockquote element.

Do you have anything more you want to share?

item.title: [html] Explain how to put dialog elements in the top layer
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Popover_API

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Popover_API#concepts_and_usage

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The page says:

Popovers which are created using the popover API are always non-modal. If you want to create a modal popover, a <dialog> element is the right way to go, although bear in mind that <dialog> elements are not put in the top layer by default popovers are.

This implies it is possible to put a <dialog> element in the top layer, but I haven't found anything explaining how to do this.

On the other hand, I'm wondering if there's a typo here. According to step 8. in this spec, <dialog> elements opened with showModal are added to the top layer.

Perhaps this paragraph intended to refer to non-modal <dialog> elements instead of all <dialog> elements; elements opened with show don't have a similar step in the spec. Either way, I'd like to see how to put a <dialog> element in the top layer when it doesn't start there.

What did you expect to see?

I expected to see a link to--or an explanation of--how to put a <dialog> element into the top layer. This information should probably be added to the <dialog> element page. When I search that page, I don't see the top layer mentioned anywhere.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/interactive-elements.html#dom-dialog-showmodal

item.title: [cssom-view-1, dom, uievents, pointerlock-2, pointerevents3, fullscreen, DOM-Parsing] MouseDown & MouseUp event articles should compare them to PointerDown & PointerUp
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/mouseup_event

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Introduction, for Mouse Up, Pointer Up, MouseDown and PointerDown

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

"The mouseup event is fired at an Element when a button on a pointing device (such as a mouse or trackpad) is released while the pointer is located inside it."

The way I interpret this is, MouseUp happens when ANY of the buttons on the mouse is released. So , if user is holding down Left and Right buttons, releases the Left, then a mouseUp happens, even though the Right button is still down.

compare with the intro for PointerUp:
"The pointerup event is fired when a pointer is no longer active."

The way I interpret this is, PointerUp only happens when the last of all the buttons is released, so zero buttons are still pressed. So , if user is holding down Left and Right buttons, releases the Left, then no PointerUp happens, because the Right button is still down. Only when hte Right button is finally released, does the PointerUP event happen.

What did you expect to see?

Is what I just wrote right? Kindof vaguely implied by comparing the PointerUp and MouseUp articles. The MouseDown article is similllarly vague, although the POinterDown article nails down the issue better:

"The pointerdown event is fired when a pointer becomes active. For mouse, it is fired when the device transitions from no buttons pressed to at least one button pressed. For touch, ...."

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://w3c.github.io/pointerevents/#dfn-chorded-buttons

Pointer Events do not fire overlapping pointerdown and pointerup events for chorded button presses (depressing an additional button while another button on the pointer device is already depressed).

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Most seriously, neither of the Mouse articles mention the Pointer events, and neither of the Pointer articles mention the Mouse events. These are important distinctions, and part of the reason why the Pointer events were invented.

Another example: the user can press the Left button down (MouseDown and PointerDown), then press and release the Right button, and no PointerDown or Up events will result, although MouseDown and Up events will happen. And, the user can then hold down both, and then release and press the Left button: Mouse Up and Down events will happen, but still no Pointer Up/Down events, because the whole time, at least one button remains pressed.

So, this relationship should be explained in one or another article(s). You can probably just expand the PointerDown article with such an explanation, and make sure the other three briefly describe it, and point to the PointerDown article for details.

item.title: [html] There is an easier way to get form data
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLFormElement/elements

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

(Not sure which section is best)

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

[I tried to edit this page myself, but could not figure out how to do it in GitHub. I have not been able to find understandable instructions for using GitHub.]

This page explains how to get a Collection of form elements. Even after converting this Collection to an array, it is still a list of elements, which is rarely needed. More common is the need for an object that maps Names to Values for each field of the form.

This is much easier to program just by using the Form element. Use form.length to get the length of the form data, then use a for loop to construct the object.

Here is a code example:

var form=document.getElementById(formID);
var pairs={};
for (var i=0; i<form.length ;i++)
    pairs[form[i].name]=form[i].value;
j=JSON.stringify(pairs,null,3);
alert(j);

item.title: [html] HTMLImageElement.srcset: sizes attribute doesn't need to be present
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLImageElement/srcset

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLImageElement/srcset#sect1

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

(Machine-translated)

On the HTMLImageElement page: srcset property - Web APIs | MDN, it is mentioned that if the srcset attribute uses width (w) descriptors, the sizes attribute must also be present, or the srcset itself will be ignored. However, according to the WHATWG HTML Standard specification, if the sizes attribute is not present, its default value is 100vw. This means that if the sizes attribute is not defined, the browser will assume that the image will always be displayed in the full width of the viewport and will select the most appropriate image from the srcset based on that assumption.

Please update the documentation to reflect this information correctly.

Thank you.

Original

En la pgina HTMLImageElement: srcset property - Web APIs | MDN, se menciona que si el atributo srcset usa descriptores de ancho (w), el atributo sizes tambin debe estar presente, o el srcset en s mismo ser ignorado. Sin embargo, segn la especificacin de WHATWG HTML Standard, si el atributo sizes no est presente, su valor predeterminado es 100vw. Esto significa que si no se define el atributo sizes, el navegador asumir que la imagen siempre se mostrar en el ancho completo del viewport y seleccionar la imagen ms adecuada del srcset en funcin de esa suposicin.

Por favor, actualicen la documentacin para reflejar esta informacin correctamente.

Gracias.

What did you expect to see?

I hope they remove the mentioned quote or correct it.

Original

Espero que eliminen la cita mencionada o que la corrijan.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

item.title: [dom] addEventListener - which browsers/events default to passive
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/addEventListener

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Improving scrolling performance with passive listeners

Documentation of which browsers default to passive

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The page says "browsers other than Safari and Internet Explorer" default certain events to passive, suggesting Chrome and Firefox do this. But it seems to be Chrome and Safari that default those events to passive.

This is also mentioned in the description of the passive flag.

What did you expect to see?

I expect it to say "Chrome and Safari change the default value of the passive option to true for {wheel, mousewheel, touchstart, touchmove}".

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

I looked up the history of the touch events defaulting to passive:

  1. 2017 https://developer.chrome.com/blog/scrolling-intervention/ Chrome says they will default touchstart, touchmove to passive
  2. 2018 WICG/interventions#18 (comment) Safari defaults touch events to passive

I've also tested the touchstart event myself to see if .cancelable is set, and

  • iOS 16.3/Safari: it's false (implying passive)
  • Android/Chrome 109: it's false (implying passive)
  • Android/Firefox 109: it's true (implying not passive)

Separately, wheel events:

  1. 2019 https://developer.chrome.com/blog/scrolling-intervention-2/ Chrome says they will default wheel events to passive, but also says that Firefox implemented the touchstart passive already (which doesn't match my tests)

I tested the wheel event to see if .cancelable is set, and

  • Mac/Safari 16.3: it's false (passive)
  • Mac/Chrome 109: it's false (passive)
  • Mac/Firefox 109: it's true (not passive)

So here too it seems to be Chrome and Safari that default to passive, not "browsers other than Safari and Internet Explorer".

Do you have anything more you want to share?

I'm happy to make a pull request but thought I should file an issue first.

item.title: [html] beforeunload event guide references custom event.returnValue, but that is deprecated
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/beforeunload_event

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

#examples, #browser_compatibility, #compatibility_notes

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Three sections of this page cover use of event.returnValue to set a custom navigate-away message:

  • The example unhelpfully shows "return event.returnValue = "Are you sure you want to exit?";" which people will no doubt copy and paste into their own code.
  • "Activation using event.returnValue = "string";"
  • "Starting with Firefox 44, Chrome 51, Opera 38, and Safari 9.1, a generic string not under the control of the webpage will be shown instead of the returned string."

However, as noted in that third point, the first example is now unhelpful as it suggests a custom message can be set.

What did you expect to see?

The following changes are needed:

  • Most importantly, the example giving return event.returnValue = "Are you sure you want to exit?"; should now presumably be return event.returnValue = '';
  • The browser compatibility table should have a new row documenting browser status showing when event.returnValue stopped being configurable with a custom message.
  • Starting with ... will be shown should be reworded to Since ... is shown as the current wording implies forthcoming rather than implemented.
  • The statement Chrome displays the string, "Do you want to leave this site? Changes you made may not be saved." should now read Chrome displays the string, "Leave site? Changes you made may not be saved."

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [html] Add a reference to to the load (et al) events on HTMLScriptElement.
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLScriptElement

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Events and See Also

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

There is no indication that there is a load event, or when it might fire.

The link to "Ryan Grove's <script> and node event compatibility chart" (i.e. https://pie.gd/test/script-link-events/) is broken.

What did you expect to see?

I expected to see the load event documented. Although the load element is defined for all elements

  • it is not listed on https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLElement
  • it seems to only fire for elements that have external content, and only when they are done loading

Given that, I think people are more likely to look for the event on the individual elements. For example, HTMLInputElement lists the input event.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

  • https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/scripting.html#execute-the-script-block (step 8)
  • https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/indices.html#event-load (in particular, the cross-references to that, which can be viewed by clicking on the event name)
  • https://web.archive.org/web/20221015042641/https://pie.gd/test/script-link-events/

Do you have anything more you want to share?

The same is probably true of the other elements that can have a load event fired for them.

item.title: [dom] Clarifying scope in event listener definition and execution
item.content:encoded:

If the opener is not on the same origin as the current page, functionality of the opener object is limited. For example, variables and functions on the window object are not accessible. However, navigation of the opener window is possible, which means that the opened page can open a URL in the original tab or window. In some cases, this makes phishing attacks possible, where a trusted page that is opened in the original window is replaced by a phishing page by the newly opened page.

item.title: [html] Using requestAnimationFrame with async DOM updating
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/window/requestAnimationFrame

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Parameters > callback

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The callback function is described, but not what happens when the argument to requestAnimationFrame is omitted.

What did you expect to see?

Calling requestAnimationFrame twice, asynchronously, with no argument, is the best method for letting the DOM update itself asynchronously and for allowing the browser screen to be repainted asynchronously. The alternative method, using setTimeout, forces a minimum delay of 4 msec.

Example code should be provided, and might look something like this:

Example 1: Disallowing time for rendering:

element.innerHTML="some text";
alert("Pausing with screen incorrect");

Example 2: Allowing time for rendering:

element.innerHTML="some text";
await YieldForFrame();
await YieldForFrame();
alert("Pausing with screen correct");

function YieldForFrame()
	{
	// Create Promise for use with 'await'
	return new Promise(function(resolve, reject)
		{
		requestAnimationFrame(resolve);
		});
	} // YieldForFrame

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

There are some Stack Overflow answers which describe this technique.

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [html, uievents] Document.activeElement : The lack of HTMLAnchorElement and macOS on a case by case basis
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/fr/docs/Web/API/Document/activeElement

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Document.activeElement

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Hello,

The introduction of the article (and the entire content) is totally focused on input elements.

The most common cases

Often activeElement will return a HTMLInputElement or HTMLTextAreaElement object.

However, in the major operating systems (OS) and browsers (I tested only on 4), the HTMLAnchorElement (A element) is focusable.

In the era of accessibility, for those who navigate with the keyboard, and for all those (everybody) who click on a link (A or an internal anchor #) : the focus is triggered and the Document.activeElement returns anHTMLAnchorElement.

And there are often more links (A links) in a page than input elements. (N.B. see examples in last part of this issue content).

This can be confusing, when you see yourself that the majority of the elements not mentioned in the article take the focus by default, in general.

The case of macOS

There is an exception on macOS (which is specified in the article), but by looking for information about Document.activeContent, it seems to me that more explanations can be provided.

Which elements are focusable varies depending on the platform and the browser's current configuration. For example, on macOS systems, elements that aren't text input elements are not typically focusable by default.

This is true, but a clarification can be added : on macOS only some browsers take into account the default configuration of the operating system : Safari and Chrome do, but Firefox and Microsoft Edge do not. (N.B. see examples in last part of this issue content).

This last information can be confusing when looing for information about Document.activeElement. Indeed, with the default macOS configuration, if when testing on Chome the A elements are not focusable but when testing on Firefox they are, the article does not really open your eyes to the macOS configuration (which is not taken into account by at least half of the browsers).

What did you expect to see?

It can be expected the HTMLAnchorElement to be referenced as a focusable element.
Alternatively, the sentence the "Often activeElement will return a HTMLInputElement or HTMLTextAreaElement object" could be modified to explain the context of this specification. The writer(s) are probably thinking of the use of Document.activeElement in the listener of a FocusEvent whose target would be a HTMLInputElement or a HTMLTextareaElement, but as a developer it is interesting to have a more global view.

Of course, the precision regarding macOS should be retained, but perhaps adding that "some elements are not typically focusable by default" is also browser dependent on macOS (regardeless the configuration). This could avoid extensive research into why it works on one browser but not the other.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

For example, on the page Document.activeElement, by counting focusable elements.

Most common cases

The HTMLAnchorElement are focusable on Linux, on Windows and on macOS (with the keyboard setting "Use keyboard navigation to move focus between controls"), and it seems that this is for all browsers :

Brower HTMLAnchorElement HTMLButtonElement HTMLInputElement
Firefox/Edge/Chrome/Safari 215 15 1

The case of macOS

On macOS, with default OS configuration (without the keyboard setting "Use keyboard navigation to move focus between controls" so) :

Brower HTMLAnchorElement HTMLButtonElement HTMLInputElement
Firefox 215 15 1
Microsoft Edge 215 15 1
Chome 0 15 1
Safari 0 0 1

item.content:encoded:

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

No response

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

In the HTML Living standard - webstorage under sessionStorage getter there is a note mentioning that there is a case when the content of the sessionStorage is copied to a new context. I think this edge case is not mentioned in the page, or not highlighted enough.
The only content which mentions this behavior is the following sentence:

Opening a page in a new tab or window creates a new session with the value of the top-level browsing context, which differs from how session cookies work.

I think this is ambiguous and does not highlight nor the copy of the content of the sessionStorage, nether the disconnect between the two sessionStorage and the "top-level browsing context" may not highlight the source of the copied sessionStorage as this is not a day-to-day expression devs may use.

What did you expect to see?

I would love to see a subsection dedicated to this behavior with the following content:

  • in what cases the content of sessionStorage copied (e.g. open a new page with window.open, iframes, etc)
  • mentions the disconnect between the contents of the two sessionStorage, so if the subpage changes the copied content, it does not applies to the source page's content
  • list the way of how to prevent the copy of sessionStorage (e.g. use noopener flag)

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

I love MDN, I love the content, I love what you did and do there. Keep up the good work!

item.title: [fetch] fetch could reject when 400 is returned
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/fetch

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Introduction and "Exceptions". At "Exceptions", the part about TypeError and the table listing all the reasons for it to happen. I didn't find anything that could justify my results in that list.

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

A fetch() promise only rejects when a network error is encountered (which is usually when there's a permissions issue or similar). A fetch() promise does not reject on HTTP errors (404, etc.). Instead, a then() handler must check the Response.ok and/or Response.status properties.

What did you expect to see?

I was expecting to trigger the execution of my success callback inside then() since http errors 4xx and 5xx should not reject the fetch promise. Instead, the error callback was executed.

It seems to me that the information in the fetch() and Fetch API pages are incorrect or outdated. I've made some tests and found that fetch is indeed rejecting promises when 400 status code is returned. I didn't try other error codes.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45899931/typeerror-failed-to-fetch-trying-to-perform-an-post-request-on-api-hosted-on-he/72552340#72552340

https://forum.freecodecamp.org/t/type-error-failed-to-fetch-when-using-fetch-api/456214/5

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Here is my test:

  • Setup a server with some POST methods and respective OPTIONS methods to support preflight requests
  • Define some required field in the request body. If the request has the field, make your server return 200. Else, return 400.
  • Send a request with and without the field and check which callback is fired inside then().

Request code example:

  function test_fetch(){
	  let message = JSON.stringify({
             // 'ids' is the expected field. Change it latter for 'id' or something else to see the error.
             ids: [1] 
	  })
  
	  fetch('http://your.api/get_data',{
		  method: 'post',
                  // Adding Content-Type header to enable preflight. 
                  // It's still not working even with normal(no-preflight) requests.
                  // To test with normal instead of preflight requests,
                  // remove the line below from the fetch options object and
                  // make sure your server can handle text/plain data or else
                  // you may face some error due to wrong parsing of request body.
		  headers: {'Content-Type': 'application/json'},
		  body: message
	  })
	  .then(data => console.log('success'),data => console.log('error'))
  }

I've tested in Chrome, version 102.0.5005.61 (Official Build) (64-bit) and Firefox, version 75.0 (64-bit). Got the same unexpected behaviour in both.

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Note: The Gamepad object is available on the gamepadconnected event rather than the Window object itself, for security reasons. Once we have a reference to it, we can query its properties for information about the current state of the gamepad. What did you expect to see?

AFAIK This wrong.

#1. While it's true a gamepad object will be provided on gamepadconnected, it's also true that gamepad objects will be provided by navigator.getGamepads

#2. The description above and elsewhere suggests holding on to a reference to the gamepad object and querying it for values. But this fails. In fact, the example code in the article does not do this. It updates the gamepad objects near the end

       controllers[gamepads[i].index] = gamepads[i];

In other words, it's updating the controllers array with a new gamepad object for the same gamepad.

If instead you did this

   // no need to use a new gamepad object if we already have a gamepad object
   // for this controller from the gamepadconnected event
   if (!controllers[gamepads[i].index]) {
      controllers[gamepads[i].index] = gamepads[i];
   }

You'd see the example would fail. At least in Chrome I get a few readings and then gamepad object I was holding a reference too goes dead. Where as if I made sure to get new gamepad objects by calling navigator.getGamepads then the code keeps running.

Let me add, holding on to a reference used to work. I was grabbing some old code that held references and I know worked great when I wrote it 7 yrs ago but suddenly it was not working. I tracked the issue down to this. You can't keep a reference to the gamepad object. You need to take new ones by calling getGamepads

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [fetch] Content bug: Inaccurate explanation on request credentials
item.content:encoded:
What page(s) did you find the problem on?

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Request/credentials
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Access-Control-Allow-Credentials

Specific page section or heading?

  • Under Syntax > Value for the request credentials page
  • The intro text for the Access-Control-Allow-Credentials page

What is the problem?

There are a few problems:

  1. Explanation on credentials weren't accurate because Authorisation headers were sent regardless whether 'credentials' were set to omit, same-origin, or include.

  1. The Access-Control-Allow-Credentials page mentioned that credentials are cookies, authorization headers, or TLS client certificates.

A few things here:

  1. Access-Control-Allow-Credentials are not required for Authorization headers. They can be sent regardless whether Access-Control-Allow-Credentials is present.
  2. Authorization headers only need Authorization to be included Access-Control-Allowed-Headers.
  3. Access-Control-Allow-Credentials are not required to send cookies between domains and subdomains. This is not listed anywhere but I thought it'll be good to make things clear.

What did you expect to see?

Three things:

  1. I recommend removing "basic http auth" from the request credentials page since it doesn't look correct.
  2. I recommend updating the pages to reflect a more accurate understanding for Access-Control-Allow-Credentials. Not sure what to update at this point, but I can take a stab at it.
  3. Maybe we can point the "etc" part in Request Credentials page to the Access-Control-Allow-Credentials page because they seem linked. I'm not sure whether this is accurate though.

Did you test this? If so, how?

I tested credentials and wrote an article about my tests. I focused on cookies in this article and didn't include the Authorization header parts. There's a test repository included in the article. I can create a test repo for the authorization part if necessary. Just let me know.

item.title: [dom] Issue with "AbortController": (missing info on behavior of .text() or .json() or other body promise)
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/AbortController

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

This was missing information about whether calling the controller.abort() function would cause the promise returned from .json(), .text(), (or any of the body-downloading functions on the resolved Request object) to fail with Uncaught DOMException: The user aborted a request. (Chrome's behavior), From experimentation, it seemed that calling controller.abort() would cancel either the request promise or the body promise, so I think that detail should be added to save others the trouble.

Specific section or headline?

2 found pages: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/AbortController and https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/AbortSignal
The section was the Note under the examples on these pages

What did you expect to see?

Details on the promise abortions returned from Response.prototype.text(), or .json(), or others.

Did you test this? If so, how?

Yep, tested chrome console interaction when downloading a large file with Slow 3G network throttling. Test code:

var ctrl = new AbortController();
var res = await fetch('https://www.ledger-cli.org/3.0/doc/ledger3.pdf', { signal: ctrl.signal });
console.log('response received');
var data = await res.text();
console.log('text downloaded');

// ^ Executed the above, then after "response received" and before "text downloaded", manually executed:
ctrl.abort();

// Resultant behavior is that "text downloaded" never was displayed, and we received this:
// (x) Uncaught DOMException: The user aborted a request.

item.title: [dom] Issue with "Document.getElementById()": link to xml:id doesn't include expected source snippet
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/getElementById

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

This is a followup to #5124

The link in the bullet point

  • xml:id - has a utility method for allowing getElementById() to obtain 'xml:id' in XML documents (such as returned by Ajax calls)

was updated to point from a broken mdn link to a specification page on w3.org. However, this page doesn't actually have the promised utility method.

The source code that the link alludes to is actually present on the mdn page at internet archive: https://web.archive.org/web/20140408083257/https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/xml/xml:id
the code in question is a simple xpath method:

var getElementByIdWrapper = function (xmldoc, myID) {
        return xmldoc.evaluate('//*[@xml:id="'+myID+'"]', xmldoc, 
                function () {
                  return 'http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace';},
                XPathResult.FIRST_ORDERED_NODE_TYPE, 
                null).singleNodeValue;
};

I'm not sure if it makes sense to include this code in-line on this doc page, for most people it'd probably introduce more confusion, however in my specific case I was actually looking for this code and didn't understand why it wasn't available on the linked w3.org page.

Specific section or headline?

"See also"

What did you expect to see?

A link to some example code to get elements in an xml document based on the xml:id attribute

item.title: [html] Content suggestion: WebSocket.readyState enum properties WebSocket.OPEN, WebSocket.CLOSING, etc
item.content:encoded:
What is the new suggestion?

WebSocket docs are missing the WebSocket.readyState enum properties WebSocket.CONNECTING, WebSocket.OPEN, WebSocket.CLOSING and WebSocket.CLOSED.

Extract from the specification:

interface WebSocket : EventTarget {
  [...]

  // ready state
  const unsigned short CONNECTING = 0;
  const unsigned short OPEN = 1;
  const unsigned short CLOSING = 2;
  const unsigned short CLOSED = 3;
  readonly attribute unsigned short readyState;
  readonly attribute unsigned long long bufferedAmount;
  [...]
}

https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/web-sockets.html#the-websocket-interface

Why is it important or useful?

This would probably need to be 4 short pages. I think this can be done in less than an hour.

Having this info will make it easier for devs to find out these properties exits and lead to better code in the ecosystem.
Not knowing they exit devs might write checks like webSocket.readyState === 1 which is confusing to readers. Devs should be enabled to write webSocket.readyState === WebSocket.OPEN by giving them this info.

Other supporting information

See: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebSocket

My contribution

I'm happy if someone fixes this but I am also willing to do it myself. However, I am unsure where to start.
Is this something that should/would be added to MDN? How are "enum states" like this usually documented? How do I go about creating these pages?

item.title: [html] Content suggestion: Add one-liner to former WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope methods
item.content:encoded:
What is the new suggestion?

See this Twitter thread: Now that the potentially-confusing WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope prefix is gone, I suggest adding a one-liner paragraph near the top saying that the global is provided both by Window and WorkerGlobalScope (with links). Something like:

Available as a global in both windows and workers (see Window and WorkerGlobalScope).

Why is it important or useful?

The one good thing about the old prefix was that if you were "in the know," it told you right away whether something was Window-only (like document) or both (like encodeURIComponent).

Other supporting information

We'd make this change on the same set of pages that used to have the WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope prefix. I don't think we need this for Window-only or WorkerGlobalScope-only properties; it looks like they already have a prefix.

I should be able to work on this next week if you'd assign it to me. Any hints on how to approach it, etc., very welcome!

item.title: [notifications, cssom-view-1, service-workers-1, dom, pointerevents3] Better naming of pages
item.content:encoded:
A big step forward was made in #8351, but I'd like to propose this rule to page naming:

  1. If the item is available on the global, use the name. Eg:
    • ServiceWorkerGlobalScope.skipWaiting becomes skipWaiting.
  2. If the item is typically reached via properties reachable from the global, use that property chain, omitting the global.
    • Document.querySelector becomes document.querySelector.
    • CacheStorage.match becomes caches.match.
  3. If the item is an instance method/property, use the constructor name with the first set of caps lower-cased + the property name.
    • Element.getBoundingClientRect becomes element.getBoundingClientRect.
    • HTMLElement.offsetHeight becomes htmlElement.offsetHeight.
  4. If the item is a static method/property, use the constructor name + the property name.
    • Notification.requestPermission remains Notification.requestPermission.
  5. Otherwise, just use the name.
    • PointerEvent remains PointerEvent

item.title: [html, web-locks] Avoiding duplication/confusion between Location+WorkerLocation and Navigator+WorkerNavigator
item.content:encoded:
mdn/browser-compat-data#9125 is a long discussion about the peculiar cases of Location+WorkerLocation and Navigator+WorkerNavigator, which are the only APIs on the web platform where distinct interfaces are used to represent the "same" thing in window and worker contexts.

For example, navigator.userAgent is available in both window and worker contexts, but navigator itself is a different kind of object. (This difference rarely matters in practice.)

BCD will follow the structure of specs/implementations, but on MDN there's duplication that might be possible to avoid. These pairs of pages and their subpages should be considered for merging or cross-linking:

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Navigator + https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerNavigator
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Location + https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerLocation

For location it's probably best to keep them separate since the worker variant is read-only. But navigator it's hard to see the usefulness of splits like this:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Navigator/languages
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerNavigator/languages
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Navigator/locks
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerNavigator/locks

item.title: [html] CustomElementRegistry needs updating
item.content:encoded:
I've been documenting ElementInternals, in the process of this I think that the documentation we have for custom elements may need some updating. In particular I noticed that https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CustomElementRegistry includes no information about the disable internals, or disable shadow booleans.

https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/custom-elements.html#concept-custom-element-definition-disable-internals

I think it would probably be worth someone taking a look at this content and seeing what else needs updating.

Once updated it would be good to link this to the information about attachInternals in /Web/API/Element/attachInternals

item.title: [console] Issue with "console", how does number formatting work? Number formatting doesn't work on Chrome.
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Console

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The section "Using string substitutions" mentions that %i and %d allow number formatting, and gives a single example, but this example does not fully explain how this is used. In addition to that, in my testing, it appears that Chrome ignores the formatting and prints out the number with %i, %d, and %f.

Specific section or headline?

Under "Using string substitutions" and under "Browser Compatibility"

What did you expect to see?

I expected to see either a description, or a link to a page with a description, on how one may use the number formatting. It isn't quite straightforward from what is written here. In addition to this, I expected to see Browser Compatibility make some mention that the formatting is ignored on Chrome.

Did you test this? If so, how?

I tested out number formatting, and (at least on chrome) the logging (log, info, warn, and error) appears to ignore number formatting. The "Browser Compatibility" section has no mention of this substitution string formatting issue.

item.title: [html] Issue with "clearTimeout()": Can failure be detected?
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope/clearTimeout

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The page says nothing about what happens if clearTimeout is too late, and fails to deactivate a setTimeout operation. In fact, it implies that failure to clear cannot be detected.

Specific section or headline?

Notes

What did you expect to see?

Usually when clearTimeout is issued, the setTimeout function is still in progress. However, there are race conditions where setTimeout is ending just as clearTimeout is issued. If setTimeout has just ended, but not yet been detected or handled, one may want clearTimeout to detect this as an error, but the MDN documentation is unclear as to whether this is possible or not. This can be an important error condition during asynchronous operations where setTimeout is used. Data loss or worse can result if we rely on clearTimeout to prevent a timeout in the rare case when the timeout has just happened, since this case cannot be detected either before or after the call to clearTimeout.

Of course, we can detect that setTimeout resolved much later, and so can eventually know that a call to clearTimeout failed, but only if we know to test for this unusual case. Either way, the documentation could be more helpful.

Did you test this? If so, how?

Asynchronous race conditions hurt my head, and can be very rare, and so I don't know how to test for them.

MDN Content page report details

item.title: [orientation-event, compat] Content bug: Improve device/screen orientation event doc
item.content:encoded:
What page(s) did you find the problem on?

A number of docs related to device orientation

Orientation and motion data explained

  • Still marked as draft
  • Does not cover DeviceMotion frame.
  • Explains only the absolute frame, not the relative frame.

Web APIs > Detecting device orientation

  • needs better linking to above doc.

  • Window.ondeviceorientationabsolute - corresponding docs missing. Looks like this is absolute-only version of orientation relative to earth frame, based on compass.

  • Window.deviceorientation_event and Window.ondeviceorientation

    • Marked experimental, but looks like the main API
    • Documented as relative to earth frame, but has absolute and relative value. Various docs indicate it is not standardised and some systems do relative, some absolute. Not clear what relative "means". So basically need to find out what relative means and what systems support what behaviour.

  • Window.orientationchange (also the event). This is the angle relative to the natural device orientation of the screen. So relative to the deviceorientation.

    • Marked as deprecated, but not clear what should be used?
    • There is also Screen.onorientationchange that is also deprecated and FF only.

  • CSS Object Model (CSSOM) > Managing screen orientation - this looks OK but refers to deprecated Screen.onorientationchange

Other relevant docs:

  • Window.devicemotion_event (and friends)
  • Google doc on topic
    Anyway,
  • Chrome 50 info on change that confuses me
  • Pretty cool tute

item.title: [notifications] Demo in Notification() constructor article causes error: The Notification permission may only be requested from inside a short running user-generated event handler
item.content:encoded:
The demo on

https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/notification/notification/index.html

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Notification/Notification

throws the following error;

The Notification permission may only be requested from inside a short running user-generated event handler.

Chromium on Android reports:

Uncaught TypeError: Failed to construct 'Notification': Illegal constructor. Use ServiceWorkerRegistration.showNotification() instead.

and ServiceWorkerRegistration.showNotification only works if google services is installed.
